newsitem.title: UK: Britain backs Eurofighter, urges integration.
newsitem.headline: Britain backs Eurofighter, urges integration.

text.p: Britain gave the green light Monday to the long-delayed Eurofighter advanced combat jet and called for more European aerospace mergers to combat the industry's U.S. giants.

The Eurofighter announcement kick-started Britain's biggest-ever air show, at which Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. fired the first salvoes in a fierce transatlantic fight for civil aviation orders.

The 40 billion pound ($60 billion) Eurofighter, delayed several years by technical hitches and political dispute, was given a major boost by Britain's carefully timed announcement to the world's leading plane buyers.

"Our assessment is that Eurofighter is the best available combat aircraft to meet the needs of the post-Cold War strategic environment," Deputy Prime Minister Michael Heseltine said at this southern English airfield.
Britain is to purchase 232 of the jets, opening the way for the production programme to start.
Heseltine urged Britain's joint venture partners in Germany, Italy and Spain to follow suit, saying: "We want a decision as quickly as we can get it."
With the U.S. aviation industry launched on a string of mergers to sharpen its challenge in an increasingly crowded market, Heseltine urged Europe to follow suit.
"This process is unstoppable and very, very desirable," he said.

Heseltine said integration was vital as research and development costs soared. "The projects of tomorrow are going to be very, very expensive," he said at the show, attended by more than 1,000 exhibitors from 60 countries.
His message was echoed by John Weston, chairman of British Aerospace Defence, lead partner in the Eurofighter consortium.

"We have developed the right aircraft at the right time and at the right price. When compared with existing combat aircraft such as the (U.S.) F-18, Eurofighter offers 2.5 times the combat capability for the same price," he said.

The Eurofighter had been dogged by political wrangling with Germany and Britain arguing over work-sharing and British Defence Minister Michael Portillo contemplating the leasing of U.S. F-16 fighters instead.
European industry leaders are increasingly vociferous in their call for governments to allow more cross-border mergers.
Insiders at British Aerospace went so far as to suggest that the company could disappear altogether within the next five years and be replaced by a single European leviathan.
The first civil aviation orders at the biennial air show were announced by U.S. giants Boeing and McDonnell Douglas.
Boeing launched a new 300-seat version of its 757 jet and announced orders totalling $6.36 billion from seven airlines.
McDonnell Douglas is selling six aircraft to four airline customers in a deal worth $365 million.
Defence companies face a dogfight in landing orders in a much reduced market. But civil aviation has shaken off recession.
"Civil aircraft traffic is set to grow by 5 percent per year in the medium term," Heseltine said. "That means a doubling of demand in the course of 15 years."
The big growth market will be the new generation of "superjumbo" jets each carrying up to almost 600 passengers.

Boeing, with its new version of its B-747 jet, is pitched against Europe's Air Industrie Group, which is developing its own 500-seater plus 3AXX. The race is on to see who will be first in the market.
